conflictDescription: User Story A implies performing exercises which likely require sensor data collection, while User Story B strictly forbids automatic activation of heart rate and step sensors unless explicitly requested, creating incompatible requirements about sensor operation.
userStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want to challenge myself with harder exercises to stay motivated and improve my health.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable only the heart rate and step sensors when I explicitly request it, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.
resolutionDescription: Modify User Story A to include explicit activation of sensors by the user and update User Story B to allow sensor use during user-initiated exercise challenges, ensuring consent and control are respected.
newUserStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want to challenge myself with harder exercises and explicitly activate heart rate and step sensors during these activities to stay motivated and improve my health.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable heart rate and step sensors only when I explicitly request it, including during exercise challenges, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires sharing most health data openly to support monitoring, while User Story B strictly forbids sharing any personal or health data for playing memory games, creating a direct contradiction on data sharing under the same system context.
userStoryASummary: As an older person, I want to share most of my health data openly without filtering so that ALFRED can fully support my health monitoring while I maintain control over my information.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person who is cautious about privacy and prefers push-to-talk interaction, I want to play simple memory games without sharing any personal or health data, so I can enjoy cognitive activities without feeling overwhelmed or exposed.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to specify distinct contexts: one for health monitoring with open data sharing, and the other for memory games with no data sharing, thus avoiding direct conflict by differentiating use cases.
newUserStoryASummary: As an older person, I want to share most of my health data openly without filtering so that ALFRED can fully support my health monitoring while I maintain control over my information during medical assessments.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person who is cautious about privacy and prefers push-to-talk interaction, I want to play simple memory games without sharing any personal or health data, so I can enjoy cognitive activities without feeling overwhelmed or exposed.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects most health data to be shared openly for full monitoring, while User Story B forbids monitoring by enabling sensors only upon explicit request, creating a contradiction in when data collection should occur.
userStoryASummary: As an older person, I want to share most of my health data openly without filtering so that ALFRED can fully support my health monitoring while I maintain control over my information.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable only the heart rate and step sensors when I explicitly request it, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to specify context-aware and consent-based data sharing policies that allow health monitoring while respecting explicit user control and privacy preferences.
newUserStoryASummary: As an older person, I want to share most of my health data openly for full monitoring by ALFRED, except when I explicitly restrict certain sensors, so that I get comprehensive support while maintaining control over sensitive information.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable heart rate and step sensors only upon explicit request or consent, ensuring that ALFRED respects my privacy and prevents unwanted continuous monitoring.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects the system to monitor health data (exercise intensity and health alerts) actively, while User Story B requires that heart rate and step sensors only activate upon explicit user request, effectively forbidding automatic or continuous monitoring; these opposing instructions on sensor activation create a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As an older adult who wants to challenge myself with harder exercises, I want to choose and adjust exercise intensity and control health alerts so that I can stay motivated and manage my health without interruptions.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable only the heart rate and step sensors when I explicitly request it, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.
resolutionDescription: Apply a context-aware policy allowing health sensors to activate automatically only during exercise sessions initiated by the user, while respecting explicit user control to prevent unwanted monitoring outside those sessions.
newUserStoryASummary: As an older adult who wants to challenge myself with harder exercises, I want to choose and adjust exercise intensity and control health alerts during my exercise sessions so that I can stay motivated and manage my health without interruptions.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want the heart rate and step sensors to activate only during my explicitly requested exercise sessions so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to activate automatically to support exercises, while User Story B prefers push-to-talk interaction only, implying no automatic activation. These opposing instructions about system activation on the same triggering context constitute a Start-Forbid conflict.
userStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want ALFRED to activate automatically to support me with daily exercises and cognitive challenges so I stay motivated and improve my health without having to start it myself.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person who is cautious about privacy and prefers push-to-talk interaction, I want to play simple memory games without sharing any personal or health data, so I can enjoy cognitive activities without feeling overwhelmed or exposed.
resolutionDescription: Introduced context-aware activation allowing automatic activation only under certain conditions and push-to-talk otherwise, reconciling the conflicting activation preferences.
newUserStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want ALFRED to activate automatically to support me with daily exercises and cognitive challenges when I opt in, so I stay motivated and improve my health without having to start it myself.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person who is cautious about privacy and prefers push-to-talk interaction, I want to play simple memory games without sharing any personal or health data and control when ALFRED activates, so I can enjoy cognitive activities without feeling overwhelmed or exposed.

conflictDescription: User Story A requires ALFRED to automatically activate to support exercises, while User Story B requires that certain sensors (heart rate and step) activate only upon explicit user request, creating opposing instructions on system activation and data monitoring.
userStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want ALFRED to activate automatically to support me with daily exercises and cognitive challenges so I stay motivated and improve my health without having to start it myself.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable only the heart rate and step sensors when I explicitly request it, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.
resolutionDescription: Apply a contextual policy layer where ALFRED automatically activates for exercises only if the user has granted prior explicit consent for sensor activation, thus reconciling automatic support with user control over data monitoring.
newUserStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want ALFRED to activate automatically to support me with daily exercises and cognitive challenges only after I have explicitly allowed sensor activation, so I stay motivated and improve my health without starting it myself.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable heart rate and step sensors only when I explicitly request it or have given prior consent, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects step-count challenges that imply automatic use of step sensors, while User Story B forbids sensor activation except on explicit user request, making automatic activation impossible under the same conditions.
userStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want to challenge myself with step-count goals that motivate me to do harder exercises while feeling in control and supported.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable only the heart rate and step sensors when I explicitly request it, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.
resolutionDescription: Adjusted both summaries to allow sensor activation for step-count challenges only after explicit user consent, balancing motivation with control over data.
newUserStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want to challenge myself with step-count goals that motivate me to do harder exercises while ensuring sensors are activated only with my permission.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable heart rate and step sensors only when I explicitly request it, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.

conflictDescription: User Story A expects ALFRED to suggest exercises spontaneously and provide feedback, implying continuous monitoring including sensors, while User Story B forbids automatic sensor activation without explicit user request, creating a direct conflict on when sensors should be active.
userStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want ALFRED to suggest varied and challenging exercises spontaneously and give informal, encouraging feedback so I stay motivated and feel supported without strict routines.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable only the heart rate and step sensors when I explicitly request it, so I can keep control over my data and prevent unwanted monitoring.
resolutionDescription: Clarify the context and conditions under which sensors are activated, allowing spontaneous exercise suggestions and feedback when explicit consent or activation occurs, thus resolving the forbid-stop conflict by merging user control with system support.
newUserStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want ALFRED to suggest varied and challenging exercises spontaneously and give informal, encouraging feedback, but only when I have explicitly authorized sensor activation, so I stay motivated and feel supported without strict routines.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person, I want to enable heart rate and step sensors only when I explicitly request it, preventing unwanted monitoring while allowing ALFRED to support me during authorized exercise sessions.

conflictDescription: User Story A implies encouraging engagement in challenging exercises (a form of prompting activity), while User Story B explicitly desires to decline medication reminders, reflecting opposing instructions regarding reminders and prompts, thus a Start-Forbid conflict on system prompting behavior under the same autonomous use context.
userStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want to take on more challenging exercises at my own pace, so I can push myself while staying in control of my health choices.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person who values privacy and autonomy, I want to be able to decline medication reminders from ALFRED to avoid feeling pressured or intrusively monitored.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to clarify context and user control, allowing challenging exercise prompts while enabling users to decline medication reminders, thus resolving the Start-Forbid conflict by contextual policy.
newUserStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult with mild mobility issues, I want to take on more challenging exercises at my own pace, so I can push myself while staying in control of my health choices, including the ability to pause prompts when desired.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person who values privacy and autonomy, I want to be able to decline medication reminders from ALFRED to avoid feeling pressured or intrusively monitored, while still receiving support for my health as I choose.

conflictDescription: User Story A implies enabling new healthcare apps that may include medication reminders, while User Story B strictly forbids receiving medication reminders to avoid feeling pressured, creating a conflict between performing and forbidding the reminder operation.
userStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult, I want to easily explore and try new healthcare apps on ALFRED to find features that help me improve my health and daily life.
userStoryBSummary: As an older person who values privacy and autonomy, I want to be able to decline medication reminders from ALFRED to avoid feeling pressured or intrusively monitored.
resolutionDescription: Both user stories are updated to introduce configurability and opt-in/out options for medication reminders, allowing exploration of new healthcare apps while respecting the preference to decline reminders to avoid pressure.
newUserStoryASummary: As a tech-curious older adult, I want to easily explore and try new healthcare apps on ALFRED that offer configurable medication reminders to help improve my health and daily life.
newUserStoryBSummary: As an older person who values privacy and autonomy, I want to be able to decline or customize medication reminders from ALFRED to avoid feeling pressured or intrusively monitored.
